chunks.original_text: 外阴内阳，外虚内实，虚涵阳气，是为冲气。 物情至此，合太和矣。 今并以丹法言之：坤交乾金，变而成坎。 坎体外虚而内实，则当以冲虚含其气，如太和之氤氲焉。 人之所恶，孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 故物或损之而益，或益之而损。 人之所教，我亦教之，强梁者不得其死，吾将以为教父。 人莫恶于名之贱，孤寡不谷，即贱名也，而王公以此自称，虽有损于名号，实有益于王公也。 故观之于物，亦有因益转损，因损得益者，玩《易》道而知之矣。 否卦，天上而地下，欲变为益，天道不敢自尊。 于是损上益下，天地不交之否运可变为自上下下之益，故君子以之迁善改过焉。 泰卦，地上而天下，欲知善损，地道不得自盈。 于是损下益上，天地相交之泰运，亦因乎其道上行之损，故君子以之惩忿窒欲焉。 天地以损而得益，是用益不如用损也。 二卦平列，却当效损卦一边。 又况山泽损，颠倒用之，则又为风雷益。 山、泽、风、雷感应，正因乎损也。 此教也，易教也，古人之教也。 太上曰：人之所教，我亦教之，益教人知自损耳。
chunks.translated_text:
Externally yin and internally yang, outwardly empty and inwardly replete—this emptiness enfolds the yang qi, and this is called the *chong qi*. When the nature of things reaches this state, it unites with the Great Harmony.

Now, speaking in terms of the elixir method: when Kun (Earth) joins with Qian (Heaven/Metal), it transforms into Kan (Water). The body of Kan is outwardly empty yet inwardly replete; thus, one should embrace its qi with *chong xu* (penetrating emptiness), like the misty harmony of the Great Harmony.

What people despise—being orphaned, widowed, or unprosperous—kings and lords take as their titles. Thus, things may be diminished yet gain, or augmented yet lose. What others teach, I also teach: "The strong and overbearing do not meet a natural end"—I take this as the father of my teaching.

Nothing is more despised than base names, yet "orphaned," "widowed," and "unprosperous" are such names, and kings and lords use them to refer to themselves. Though their titles are diminished, in truth, they gain thereby. Thus, observing things, one sees that gain may turn to loss, and loss may yield gain—this is known through contemplating the Way of the *Yi*.

In the *Pi* hexagram, Heaven is above and Earth below; to transform this into benefit, the Way of Heaven does not dare exalt itself. Thus, it diminishes above to augment below, and the stagnation of Heaven and Earth not joining may become the benefit of the above descending to the below. Therefore, the noble person uses this to reform faults and amend errors.

In the *Tai* hexagram, Earth is above and Heaven below; to know the good of diminution, the Way of Earth does not presume to be full. Thus, it diminishes below to augment above, and the harmony of Heaven and Earth joining also follows the principle of the above acting through diminution. Therefore, the noble person uses this to curb anger and restrain desires.

Heaven and Earth gain through loss—thus, employing gain is not as effective as employing loss. Though the two hexagrams stand side by side, one should emulate the side of *Sun* (Diminution). Moreover, when *Shan Ze Sun* (Mountain and Marsh Diminishing) is inverted, it becomes *Feng Lei Yi* (Wind and Thunder Benefiting). The resonance of mountain, marsh, wind, and thunder arises precisely from diminution.

This is the teaching—the teaching of the *Yi*, the teaching of the ancients. The Most High said: "What others teach, I also teach—to teach people to know self-diminution."

chunks.original_text: 不善者，善人之资，故又以强梁为教父。 强梁乃劫夺之徒，损人益己，终不得益者也。 父与甫同，从上声。 第四十三章 （河上公注本作偏用章，彭本作至柔章） 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有入于无间，吾是以知无为之有益。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 至柔者：气与水也。 气无不达之窍，水无不通之径，故能驰骋至坚而无间也。 山吐石，泉穿山，可见也。 无有者，无形质而但有气水，亦可达吾身而入无间也。 上二句泛言天下之气水，此句指身中言，譬起法也。 又曰：“吾是以无为之有益。 ”无为者，不必搬运，自然冲突也。 以不言之教，合无为之益，天下真无有及之者。 第四十四章 （河上公注本作立戒章，彭本作为名章） 名与身孰亲？ 身与货孰多？ 得与亡孰病？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 身亲于名，身多于货。 得身无病，亡身有病。 此理之晓然者也。 故太上以孰亲、孰多、孰病觉之，所以动其良心，使人自悟，非同乎后世训文，一味责备，反令舆情不服。 此太上谦和之德也。 然世有亲其名而疏其身，多其货而少其身，得身不以为贵，亡身不以为痛者。 如此沉迷，要皆名利心重，保身心轻者也。 岂如喉中气断，大限来临，名归乌有，货归子虚，亡入鬼趣，难复人身，是则可痛也已！ 夫人生在世，成我名者损我神，入悖货者亦悖出，即所谓甚爱大费，多藏厚亡者也。 爱至于大费，是辱也。 藏至于厚亡，是殆也。 皆非长久之计也。 太上以慈悲之心，立言觉以教人曰：“知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 ”其斯为圣人之德也夫。 第四十五章
chunks.translated_text:
The unskilled serve as the resource for the skilled—thus, the strong and overbearing are called the "teaching fathers." The strong and overbearing are those who seize and plunder, diminishing others to augment themselves, yet in the end gain nothing. *Fu* (father) here shares the same pronunciation as *fu* (beginning), read in the rising tone.

**Chapter Forty-Three**
*(He Shanggong’s commentary titles this "Partial Application"; Peng’s edition titles it "Utmost Softness")*

The softest under Heaven gallops through the hardest under Heaven. The non-existent enters where there is no gap—thus do I know the benefit of non-action. The teaching without words, the benefit of non-action—few under Heaven can attain this.

The "utmost soft" refers to *qi* and water. *Qi* reaches every unobstructed aperture; water finds every unblocked path—thus they gallop through the hardest without gap. Mountains disgorge stones; springs pierce mountains—this is visible. The "non-existent" refers to that without form or substance, only *qi* and water, which can likewise reach our bodies and enter where there is no gap.

The first two lines speak generally of *qi* and water under Heaven; this line refers specifically to the body, setting forth the analogy. It further states: "Thus do I know the benefit of non-action." Non-action means no forced movement, only natural surging. To unite the teaching without words with the benefit of non-action—truly, none under Heaven can match this.

**Chapter Forty-Four**
*(He Shanggong’s commentary titles this "Establishing Admonitions"; Peng’s edition titles it "Valuing the Name")*

Which is closer—name or self?
Which is greater—self or wealth?
Which is more harmful—gain or loss?

Therefore, excessive attachment incurs great expense; hoarding leads to heavy loss. Knowing contentment avoids disgrace; knowing when to stop avoids danger—this is how one endures.

The self is closer than the name; the self is greater than wealth. Gaining the self brings no harm; losing the self brings harm. This principle is self-evident.

Thus, the Most High uses "which is closer," "which is greater," and "which is more harmful" to awaken people, stirring their innate conscience so they may realize for themselves—not like later generations’ didactic texts, which merely reproach and instead provoke resistance. This is the Most High’s humility and harmony.

Yet in the world, some grow close to their name while estranging their self, amass wealth while diminishing their self, value gain over the self, and feel no pain at its loss. Such deep delusion stems from prizing fame and profit while neglecting self-preservation.

How pitiful when the last breath is drawn, the final hour arrives, the name vanishes into nothingness, wealth becomes an empty fiction, and the lost one falls into ghostly realms, never to regain human form!

For one living in the world, what builds my name depletes my spirit; what enters through perversity exits likewise—this is what is meant by "excessive attachment incurs great expense; hoarding leads to heavy loss." Attachment that incurs great expense is disgrace; hoarding that leads to heavy loss is danger—neither is a path to endurance.

With a heart of compassion, the Most High speaks to awaken and teach: "Knowing contentment avoids disgrace; knowing when to stop avoids danger—this is how one endures." Such is the virtue of the sage.

chunks.original_text: （河上公注本作洪德章，彭本作清静章） 大成若缺，其用不敝。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热。 清静为天下正。 大成若缺，如日月之光，圆而暂亏，推而复明，故其用不敝也。 大盈若冲，如沧海之量，统而不溢，渺而无涯，故其用不穷也。 亢直者卤，机巧者诈，强辩者诬，皆不可同乎大也。 圣贤以气为直，不逞刚而自刚，若屈然，神妙为巧。 不显智而自智，若拙然，以道行德为辩。 不多言而善言，若讷然。 至若铅火冲和，三冬足御，蒲团坐定，九夏可忘，正所谓躁胜寒，静胜热也。 此二者，阴阳之理，人能以清虚静养之心，察燥湿冷暖之气，而天下之正道得矣。 第四十六章 （河上公注本作俭欲章，彭本作知足章）
chunks.translated_text:
The Great Achievement appears deficient, yet its function never wears out.
The Utmost Fullness appears empty, yet its function is inexhaustible.
The Utmost Straightness appears bent,
the Utmost Skill appears clumsy,
the Utmost Eloquence appears inarticulate.

Restlessness overcomes cold; stillness overcomes heat.
Clarity and stillness are the correct governance of the world.

The Great Achievement appears deficient—like the light of the sun and moon, round yet temporarily eclipsed, advancing to regain its brightness, thus its function never wears out.
The Utmost Fullness appears empty—like the vastness of the sea, embracing all without overflow, boundless and without limit, thus its function is inexhaustible.
Those who are excessively straight are reckless;
those who rely on cunning are deceitful;
those who force eloquence are false—
none can compare to the great.

The sage and worthy use qi to attain straightness,
not flaunting hardness yet inherently hard, appearing bent;
their divine subtlety becomes skill,
not displaying wisdom yet inherently wise, appearing clumsy;
their virtue and Dao become eloquence,
not speaking much yet speaking well, appearing inarticulate.

As for refining lead and fire into harmony,
three winters can be endured;
sitting steadfast on a rush cushion,
the heat of nine summers can be forgotten—
this is precisely what is meant by "restlessness overcomes cold; stillness overcomes heat."
These two principles embody the workings of yin and yang.
If one can observe the qi of dryness and dampness, cold and warmth
with a heart of clarity, emptiness, and stillness,
then the correct Way of the world is attained.

chunks.original_text: 天下有道，却走马以粪。 天下无道，戎马生于郊。 罪莫大于可欲，祸莫大于不知足，咎莫大于欲得，故知足之足，常足。 有道：是否运既久，阴极阳来之时。 无道，是泰运既久，阳极阴生之时。 否乱定而泰治立，则却走马以粪田，天下事已无极也。 泰治盛而否乱伏，则生戎马于近郊，天下事将有为也。 乱而复始，泰定为福。 见可欲而欲，罪莫大焉。 已足不知足，祸莫大焉。 不当得也欲得，咎莫大焉。 故以知足为足者，则能常足矣。 补注：却：去也。 粪：治也。 天下无事，虽不用马而马在。 却之云者，去之于山泽，如归马之意云耳。 又马本不可以治田，其言以粪者，犹言兵去农兴也。 第四十七章 （河上公注本作鉴远章，彭本作户牖章）
chunks.translated_text:
When the world follows the Dao, warhorses are retired to fertilize the fields. When the world loses the Dao, even mares in the wild give birth on the battlefield.

No crime is greater than indulging desire; no disaster is greater than discontent; no fault is greater than covetousness. Thus, contentment in sufficiency is perpetual sufficiency.

"Following the Dao" refers to the time when the *yin* phase has reached its extreme and *yang* begins to rise after a long period of *pi* (adversity). "Losing the Dao" refers to the time when the *tai* (prosperity) phase has lasted too long and *yin* begins to emerge from the extreme of *yang*. When *pi* (adversity) is resolved and *tai* (order) is established, warhorses are retired to fertilize the fields—nothing in the world remains unaccomplished. When *tai* (prosperity) flourishes and *pi* (disorder) lies dormant, warhorses are bred even in the outskirts—affairs of the world demand action. Yet from disorder, renewal begins, and *tai* (order) brings blessing.

To see what is desirable and desire it—no crime is greater. To be content yet remain discontent—no disaster is greater. To covet what one ought not—no fault is greater. Therefore, one who finds sufficiency in contentment attains perpetual sufficiency.

**Supplementary Note:**
*Que* (却) means "to remove." *Fen* (粪) means "to cultivate." When the world is at peace, though horses are unused, they still exist. To "remove" them means to send them to the mountains and marshes, akin to the idea of "returning horses to pasture." Moreover, horses are not meant for tilling fields; the phrase "to fertilize" is used as a metaphor for the withdrawal of arms and the rise of agriculture.

chunks.original_text: 不出户，知天下。 不窥牖，见天道。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，不为而成。 户：小门。 以不出而知天下事，匡居所以明世务也。 牖：小窗也。 不窥而见天之道，隐微所以伏见显也。 身心性命，道所寄焉。 舍近图远，愚人也。 视不可见，听不可闻，抟不可得，彼从何处寻起？ 知此义者，道在户牖之间。 不知此义者，愈访愈迷，愈问愈歧。 条条皆是路，处处却难周。 所谓出弥远而知弥少也。 惟圣人不行而知，神定则意慧。 不见而名，守无则生有。 不为而成，抱一以还虚。 第四十八章 （河上公注本作忘知章，彭本作日损章） 为学日益，为道日损。 损之又损，以至于无为。 无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 为学与为道不同，学贵求益也，然有由博反约者，益又何尝不损？ 特其先必求益耳。 道贵求损也，然有事累而立基者，道又何尝不益？ 特其后必知损耳。 夫损者，抽减之谓也。 损而又损，铅气干，汞光现，以至于养神还虚，行我无为之事，斯无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，必先有奠安天下之心，无为无不为，以静制动，以德为常，以仁修治，百姓携手而同归，万国倾心而来会，则可以取天下矣。 故必常以无事也。 及其有事，必先有震荡天下之声，有为而多为，以动克动，以残摧残，以暴易暴。 以争战为能，以袭夺为事，适以扰天下，先天下也，何以取天下乎？ 或谓取天下者，常以无事之人，肩有事之任，古来如莘野、磻溪、南阳诸道人是也。 及其有事在心，则方寸已乱，如范增之忌刘、徐元直之为母是也，亦通。 第四十九章 （河上公注本作任德章，彭本作浑心章） 圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之。 德善矣。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之。 德信矣。 圣人在天下，惵惵为天下浑其心，百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 无常心者，无偏一之心也。 心无所偏，则能屏幪百姓，浃洽民心。 民心所望者，望圣人善之、信之也。 不善者亦善，不信者亦信，圣德之诚孚大矣。 故圣人在天下，惵惵为天下浑其心者，屏幪百姓耳。 百姓皆注其耳目，仰视俯听，各有所望，圣人皆孩之，斯浑之矣。 迭迭：诚切貌。 第五十章 （河上公注本作贵生章，彭本作摄生章） 出生入死。 生之徒，十有三。 死之徒，十有三。 民之生，动之死地，亦十有三。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚。
chunks.translated_text:
He who does not step beyond his door knows the world.
He who does not peer through his window sees the Dao of Heaven.
The farther he ventures, the less he knows.
Thus the sage knows without traveling, names without seeing, accomplishes without acting.

*Hu* (户): a small door. By not going out yet knowing worldly affairs, seclusion clarifies worldly matters.
*You* (牖): a small window. Without peering yet seeing Heaven’s Dao, the hidden and subtle reveal the manifest.
Body, mind, nature, and life—these are where the Dao resides.
To abandon the near and pursue the distant is the way of fools.
What cannot be seen, heard, or grasped—where does one begin the search?
He who understands this truth finds the Dao between door and window.
He who does not grows ever more lost with each inquiry, more confused with each question.
Every path seems right, yet none can be fully traversed—
this is what it means to venture farther and know less.

Only the sage knows without traveling, for when the spirit is settled, wisdom arises.
He names without seeing, for holding to non-being gives rise to being.
He accomplishes without acting, for embracing the One returns to emptiness.

**Chapter Forty-Eight**
In the pursuit of learning, one gains daily.
In the pursuit of the Dao, one loses daily.
Lose and lose again, until one reaches non-action.
Through non-action, nothing is left undone.
Thus he who would govern the world must always act without interference.
If he interferes, he is unfit to govern the world.

The pursuit of learning differs from the pursuit of the Dao.
Learning values accumulation, yet even in learning, one may progress from breadth to simplicity—what was gained is not without loss.
The Dao values reduction, yet even in the Dao, one may establish a foundation through worldly affairs—what was lost is not without gain.
Reduction means to strip away.
Lose and lose again, until the leaden *qi* dries and the mercury’s light appears,
until one nurtures the spirit and returns to emptiness,
acting through my non-action—
thus nothing is left undone.

To govern the world, one must first settle the world with a steadfast heart.
Act through non-action, and nothing is left undone.
Respond to movement with stillness, make virtue the constant,
cultivate governance with benevolence—
then the people will join hands and come together,
and all nations will turn their hearts toward unity.
Thus one may govern the world.
This is why one must always act without interference.
If one interferes, there will first be upheaval across the land.
Acting through action, one multiplies action,
meeting force with force, destruction with destruction, violence with violence.
To make war one’s skill and plunder one’s task
is to disturb the world and put oneself before it—
how can one govern the world thus?

Some say that those who govern the world must be men of non-action shouldering the burdens of action,
as were the recluses of Xinye, Panxi, and Nanyang in ancient times.
Yet when the affairs of the world weigh on their hearts,
their minds become disordered—
as with Fan Zeng’s grudge against Liu Bang or Xu Yuanzhi’s devotion to his mother.
This interpretation also holds.

**Chapter Forty-Nine**
The sage has no fixed heart; he takes the hearts of the people as his own.
To the good, I am good; to the not-good, I am also good—thus virtue is goodness.
To the trustworthy, I am trustworthy; to the untrustworthy, I am also trustworthy—thus virtue is trustworthiness.

When the sage is in the world, he humbly unifies his heart with the world.
The people all turn their ears and eyes toward him, and the sage treats them all as children.

Having no fixed heart means having no partiality.
With no partiality, he can shield and embrace the people, harmonizing with their hearts.
What the people hope for is that the sage will treat them with goodness and trustworthiness.
Even the not-good and the untrustworthy receive goodness and trustworthiness—
how great is the sincerity of the sage’s virtue!

Thus when the sage is in the world, humbly unifying his heart with the world,
he shields and embraces the people.
The people all turn their ears and eyes toward him, each with their own hopes,
and the sage treats them all as children—thus he unifies them.
*Diedie* (惵惵): the appearance of sincerity.

**Chapter Fifty**
From birth one enters death.
Those who follow life are thirteen in number.
Those who follow death are thirteen in number.
Those who live yet move toward the realm of death are also thirteen in number.
Why is this so?
Because they overindulge in the pursuit of life.

*Que* (却) means "to remove." *Fen* (粪) means "to cultivate." When the world is at peace, though horses are unused, they still exist. chunks.original_text: 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，入军不被（一作进）甲兵。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 夫何故？ 以其无死地。 万物出生而入死，皆在乎十有三中。 夫十有三者，向来诸注，皆不得其正旨，今发明之。 十乃天地生成之数。 一天、一地，一乾、一坤，乾卦有三阳，坤卦有三阴。 万物遇三阳而生，遇三阴而死。 惟人之受生，其得三阳与物同，其入三阴则自促。 七情六欲，大损元神，故曰动之死地。 然其自促也，亦归于三阴而已。 夫物与人，而有三生、三死者，何以故？ 生生厚，则死者既灭，生者又添。 死者既静，生者又动。 此循环相因之势也。 否则有生无死，将芸芸充塞天下，何以为安顿之区乎？ 虽然万物之死在于冬，万物之生在于春，其生死亦动静间耳。 至于人则死而不生，非造化之刻待斯人也，亦因其不知养生，乃致长入死地耳。 夫上帝有厚生之德，圣人有摄生之方，人苟善求，即宜转阳生阴死之道，为阳往阴来之功，则长生久视，庶不与乍生之徒，动之死地者同之。 物有三而生，又有三而死。 摄生之道，则即以三阳之乾卦种一阳于三阴中，坤遂实而成坎。 三阴之坤卦，萌一阴于三阳之中，乾遂虚而成离。 坎离者，药物也。 入室静修，观我一阳来复，即行摄之而归，摄之而伏。 是摄生乃还丹之道，返本之功，接命之术，成仙之诀。 逆而回之乃为摄，下而上之乃为摄，外而内之乃为摄，中有黄婆乃能摄。 摄非易言者也。 子母恋而养育深，婴姹偕而欢喜大，铅汞结而圣胎成，无为证而阳神出。 虽虎兕甲兵，亦无所肆厄，又何有三阳而生、三阴而死，同夫凡人凡物也哉？ 第五十一章 （河上公注本作养德章，彭本作尊贵章） 道生之，德畜之，物形之，势成之。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之命而常自然。 故道生之，德畜之、长之、育之，成之、熟之，养之、覆之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰。 是谓玄德。 道种物，德护物，故物以道生，而以德畜。 物吐形，能势乃能成。 万物尊道而贵德，以道无名，德有名； 道之尊，德之贵。 道德无使令，物理自然会。 惟道主其生，惟德主畜。 长育而成熟。 而养覆。 帱保全神，皆德之伎俩。 不有、不恃、亦不宰，无为而成即真解。 玄德者，上德也。 第五十二章 （河上公注本作归元章，彭本作有始章） 天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子。 既知其子，复守其母，没身不殆。 塞其兑，闭其门，终身不勤。 开其兑，济其事，终身不救。 见小曰明，守柔曰强。 用其光，复归其明，无遗身殃。 是谓袭常。 天下之道，有终必有始，然其始非一端也。 金丹有始出之地，始行之事，始复之物。 始出者何？ 坤炉与阴炉是也。 阴中藏阳，故名阴阳炉。 月现兑方，故名偃月炉。 兑为少女，故名先天妙鼎。 《悟真》谓“产药川源”，皆始地也。 始行者何？ 致虚极，守静笃，吾以观其复。 浊以澄，静之徐清，安以久，候之徐生。 皆始事也。 始复者何？ 混混成成，窈窈冥冥，其中有信，其中有精。 无名之朴，无形之金，皆始物也。 还丹以此金为始，故曰有始。 然金非坤家故有之物，乃乾家之火精也。 丹法以砂为主，入坤炉而成坎，禀和于玉池之水银以成戊土，戊土即阳丹也。

---

It is said that those who skillfully nurture life walk on land without encountering rhinoceroses or tigers, and enter battle without being harmed by weapons. The rhinoceros has nowhere to thrust its horn, the tiger nowhere to place its claws, and weapons nowhere to lodge their blades. Why is this so? Because they dwell not in the realm of death.

All things emerge into life and enter death, all falling within the thirteen. As for these thirteen, past commentaries have not grasped their true meaning, which I now clarify. The number ten represents the generative numbers of Heaven and Earth. One Heaven, one Earth; one *qian*, one *kun*. The *qian* hexagram has three yang lines, the *kun* hexagram three yin lines. All things meet the three yang and are born, meet the three yin and die. Only humans, in receiving life, share the three yang with other beings, yet their entry into the three yin is self-accelerated. The seven emotions and six desires greatly harm the original spirit, hence it is said they "move toward the realm of death." Yet even this self-acceleration returns to the three yin alone.

Why do beings and humans have three births and three deaths? When the pursuit of life is excessive, the dead are extinguished, and the living are replenished. The dead are at rest, the living in motion—this is the cyclical, interdependent pattern. Otherwise, if there were life without death, the teeming multitudes would fill the world; how could there be a place of repose?

Though the death of all things lies in winter and their birth in spring, their life and death are but the alternation of movement and stillness. For humans, however, death does not return to life. This is not because creation singles out humanity for harsh treatment, but because they do not know how to nurture life, thus continually entering the realm of death.

The Supreme Lord possesses the virtue of cherishing life, and the sage possesses the method of nurturing life. If one seeks wisely, one should transform the path of "yang birth and yin death" into the work of "yang departing and yin arriving," thereby attaining long life and enduring vision, no longer sharing the fate of those who, though newly born, move toward the realm of death.

Things are born through three and die through three. The Way of nurturing life thus takes the three yang of the *qian* hexagram and plants one yang within the three yin, so that *kun* becomes substantial and forms *kan*. The three yin of the *kun* hexagram sprout one yin within the three yang, so that *qian* becomes hollow and forms *li*. *Kan* and *li* are the medicinal substances. Entering seclusion and cultivating stillness, one observes the return of one’s solitary yang, then gathers and returns it, gathers and subjugates it. Thus nurturing life is the Way of the Returned Elixir, the work of returning to the root, the art of extending life, the secret of becoming an immortal.

To reverse and return is nurturing; to move from below to above is nurturing; to turn from outer to inner is nurturing; only with the Yellow Dame within can one nurture. Nurturing is not easily spoken of. Mother and child cherish each other, and nurturing runs deep; the infant and maiden unite, and joy is great; lead and mercury conjoin, and the sacred embryo forms; through non-doing, one verifies and the yang spirit emerges. Though tigers, rhinoceroses, and weapons may assail, they have no power to bring calamity. How then could one share the three yang for birth and three yin for death with ordinary people and things?

**Chapter Fifty-One**
The Dao gives them life, virtue nourishes them, things shape them, and conditions complete them. Therefore, all things without exception revere the Dao and honor virtue. The reverence for the Dao and the honor for virtue arise not by command but always naturally.

Thus the Dao gives them life, virtue nourishes, rears, raises, completes, ripens, tends, and shelters them. It gives life yet does not possess, acts yet does not rely, leads yet does not dominate—this is called profound virtue.

The Dao sows things, virtue protects them; thus things are born by the Dao and nourished by virtue. Things manifest form, and through conditions they are completed. All things revere the Dao and honor virtue because the Dao is nameless while virtue has a name. The reverence for the Dao and the honor for virtue arise without command, for the principles of things naturally converge.

Only the Dao presides over their birth, only virtue presides over their nourishment. It rears and raises, completes and ripens, tends and shelters. Preserving and protecting the spirit are all the arts of virtue. Not possessing, not relying, nor dominating, accomplishing through non-doing—this is true understanding. Profound virtue is the highest virtue.

**Chapter Fifty-Two**
The world has a beginning, which serves as the mother of the world. Having attained the mother, one knows her children. Having known the children, one again guards the mother, and to the end of life one does not perish.

Block the openings, shut the gates, and to the end of life one will not toil. Open the openings, aid one’s affairs, and to the end of life one will not be saved. Seeing the small is called clarity, guarding the soft is called strength. Use its light, return to its clarity, and one will leave no calamity for the self. This is called inheriting the constant.

The Way of the world has an end and thus a beginning, yet its beginning is not singular. The Golden Elixir has a place from which it first emerges, a practice with which it first proceeds, and a substance to which it first returns.

What is the place of first emergence? The *kun* furnace and the yin furnace are one. Yin conceals yang, hence it is called the yin-yang furnace. The moon appears in the *dui* direction, hence it is called the inverted moon furnace. *Dui* is the youngest maiden, hence it is called the primordial wondrous tripod. The *Awakening to Reality* calls it the "source of medicinal production"—all are places of beginning.

What is the practice of first proceeding? To reach the utmost emptiness, to guard perfect stillness, I observe their return. Turbidity settles and slowly clears; tranquility endures, and slowly life emerges—all are the first practices.

What is the substance of first return? The undifferentiated and complete, the profound and obscure—within it there is sincerity, within it there is essence. The uncarved block without name, the formless gold—all are the first substances. The Returned Elixir takes this gold as its beginning, hence it is said to have a beginning. Yet this gold is not a native substance of the *kun* household; it is the fiery essence of the *qian* household.

The elixir method takes cinnabar as its primary agent. Entering the *kun* furnace, it forms *kan*, harmonizing with the mercury of the Jade Pond to become *wu* earth—*wu* earth is the yang elixir.

The yang elixir is the external elixir, and the external elixir is the root of the elixir. The Golden Flower is it, the True Seed is it, the Yellow Sprout is it, the White Snow is it. Taking the external elixir as the mother of the internal elixir, thus it is said to have a beginning as the Mother of All Under Heaven. The mother has a sacred name, called Yang Lead. Where there is Yang Lead as mother, there is Yin Mercury as child. Yin Mercury is the postnatal qi of the child, while Yang Lead is the prenatal qi of the mother. When the external Yang Lead subdues the internal Yin Mercury, mother and child meet—hence it is said, "Know the child."

Yet this coming of Yang Lead requires the wondrous application of fire. For Lead is born in the *kan* palace, sunken and unmoving. To capture and restrain the true Mercury of the *li* palace, one must employ fierce fire for intense refinement, whereupon it soars upward. After meeting with true Mercury, one should then guard the city and bathe, refraining from applying fierce fire. At first, the mother comes longing for the child; later, the child lingers longing for the mother—thus it is said, "Having known the child, return to guard the mother." When mother and child long for one another without end, the Great Elixir is accomplished.

The Great Elixir is called the internal medicine; the Sacred Embryo is this, the Infant is this, the True Person is this. In nurturing the internal elixir, one must possess the natural true fire, continuously simmering within the earthen crucible, and also employ the external furnace’s yin-yang talismanic fire, diligently adjusting its intensity. Through the operations of withdrawal and addition, form is transformed into qi, and qi into spirit. When form and spirit are both wondrous, they unite with the Dao in truth. Thus one must block the *dui*, close the gate, and devote oneself to this practice for life.

There are two kinds of nurturing: the internal civil fire and the external talismanic fire. Preserving it for ten months, one abandons effortful action to realize effortless action—hence one dare not busy oneself with external affairs, disturbing the inner stillness of the chamber. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Securely seal their juncture, striving to make it complete and firm. Observe and attend with utmost care, carefully regulating warmth and coolness. Circulate through the twelve nodes, and when each node is exhausted, renew your closeness." This is the work of nurturing.

The inner realm does not leak outward, the outer realm does not intrude inward—blocking the *dui* and closing the gate is the essential technique. If one does not block the *dui*, one will daily engage with external affairs. Daoists often discuss worldly matters, wishing to aid external endeavors, yet first harming their inner cultivation. When the mouth opens, spirit and qi scatter; when the mind is disordered, the fire’s work grows cold. The great path of longevity, I fear, will not be achieved—hence it is said, "If you assist in such affairs, you will never recover for life."

The "small" refers to the golden light of the elixir, its form like a grain of millet—thus it is called "small." To see this small is called "bright." The "yielding" refers to the body’s royal water, whose qi is fundamentally harmonious—thus it is called "yielding." To guard this yielding is called "strong." The "light" is spirit, the very golden light. The "bright" is qi, the very golden essence. When golden light envelops golden essence, light and brightness are concealed within, spirit and qi interdependent. The work of embryo nurturing is accomplished, and the body escapes calamity—thus it is said, "Use its light, return to its brightness, leaving no misfortune for the body." This is the Way of inheriting the constant, the cultivation of long life and enduring vision.

To "inherit the constant" is to guard one’s true constancy. My mountain appraisal: This chapter is clarified sentence by sentence, each word extracted with precision—the Way of the Returned Elixir is fully revealed here. I have often said that the scriptures of the Most High are concise yet comprehensive, even true immortals cannot fully comprehend them—how exceptionally clear is this commentary! How joyous! How delightful!

chunks.original_text: 第五十三章 （河上公注本作益证章，彭本作介然章） 使我介然有知，行于大道，惟施是畏。 大道甚夷，而民好径。 朝甚除，田甚芜，仓甚虚。 服文彩，带利剑，厌饮食，财货有余，是谓盗竿。 非道也哉！ 我：言我家也，非老圣自称之词也。 介然：特操也。 我家性体圆明，使我介然自定，有特操，有圆觉。 躬行大道，唯施是畏。 施则顺出成凡，多损我之真精，故以是为可畏也。 夫积精累气可以成真，此大道平夷之路，人所共由者也。 民心好径，争入邪途。 妄作招凶，精枯神散。 如朝廷之故官，既行除削，则元阳之尽失也。 如田畴之疆畔，胥入荒芜，则关窍之皆塞也。 如仓廪之积储，咸归虚耗，则精气之皆亡也。 彼但服文彩，带利剑，征逐于饮食之徒，妄想乎资财之足。 若是者，专以窃道名为心，如人隔墙用竿，暗挑物件，是称为盗竿而已。 必非道哉！ 必非道哉！

Chapter Fifty-Three
*(He Shang Gong’s commentary titles this the "Chapter of Increasing Evidence"; Peng’s version calls it the "Chapter of Unwavering Resolve")*

Were I to possess unwavering knowledge,
I would walk the great Dao,
fearing only deviation.
The great Dao is utterly smooth,
yet the people prefer byways.

Courts are swept clean,
fields lie fallow,
granaries stand empty.
They don fine brocades,
gird themselves with sharp swords,
surfeit on food and drink,
hoard wealth in excess—
this is called the "thieving pole."
How far from the Dao!

*I*: refers to my lineage, not the Old Sage’s self-reference.
*Unwavering (介然)*: steadfast resolve.
My lineage’s nature is perfectly luminous;
were I to stabilize myself with unwavering resolve,
I would possess both steadfastness and complete awakening.
To personally walk the great Dao,
fearing only deviation—
for deviation follows outward dispersion,
greatly depleting my true essence,
and thus is to be feared.

Accumulating essence and amassing qi
can refine one into truth—
this is the great Dao’s level path,
the shared road all should follow.
Yet the people’s hearts prefer byways,
competing to enter crooked paths.
Delusion invites misfortune;
essence withers, spirit scatters.

Like a court’s former halls,
once purged and stripped,
the primordial yang is utterly lost.
Like fields’ boundaries,
all fallen to waste,
the gates and orifices are wholly blocked.
Like granaries’ stores,
all reduced to emptiness,
the essence and qi are entirely gone.

They merely don fine brocades,
gird themselves with sharp swords,
chase after feasts and revelry,
vainly imagining their wealth sufficient.
Such ones fix their hearts on pilfering the Dao’s name,
like thieves who use poles to hook objects over walls—
this is called the "thieving pole" and nothing more.
How far from the Dao!
How far from the Dao!

chunks.original_text: 第五十四章 （河上公注本作修观章，彭本作善建章） 善建者不拔，善抱者不脱，子孙祭祀不辍。 修之于身，其德乃真。 修之于家，其德乃余。 修之于乡，其德乃长。 修之于国，其德乃丰。 修之于天下，其德乃普。 故以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以国观国，以天下观天下。 吾何以知天下之然哉？ 以此。 建中立极，故不拔。 抱一无离，故不脱。 子复生孙，分身现化，故祭祀不辍。 身家乡国与天下，历言修德之地也。 以：由也。 观：示法也。 由身示法身，以及示法身于家、国、天下，皆此真身也。 德备于身，示法无尽，故以此周知天下也。 第五十五章 （河上公注本作玄符章，彭本作含德章） 含德之厚，比于赤子。 毒虫不螫，猛兽不据，攫鸷不抟。 骨弱筋柔而握固。 未知牝牡之合而朘作，精之至也。 终日号嗌不嗄，和之至也。 知和曰常，知常曰明。 益生曰祥。 心使气曰强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 含：怀也。 怀德厚者，真人也。 真人之心，不失赤子之心，故比于赤子，浑然忘物。 斯恶虫兽鸟，不加害焉。 骨弱筋柔，孩体也，故能握固。 人知牝牡交欢，则朘作丧命。 赤子无知，则精纯之至，盖无欲也。 朘，赤子之阴也，又，缩也。 俗以肭缩为朘缩，盖缩而不举也。 人以忿而和气变，其声嗄然，赤子则有号、有嗌而无嗄。 号乃呼也，嗌乃咽也。 终日呼咽而不嗄，则气和之至也。 人能知和，则守常不殆。 我能知常，则真明自在。 盖有益于人生者，赤子祥和之气也。 倘其有知有识，以心使气，则反乎柔而为强矣。 世之好强者，亦尝观之于物乎。 末三句解见前三十章。 第五十六章
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Fifty-Four**
*(He Shang Gong’s commentary titles this "The Chapter on Cultivating Observation"; Peng’s edition titles it "The Chapter on Skillful Establishment")*

What is skillfully established cannot be uprooted;
what is skillfully embraced cannot slip away.
Thus descendants’ sacrifices never cease.

Cultivate it in the self—its virtue becomes true.
Cultivate it in the family—its virtue becomes abundant.
Cultivate it in the village—its virtue becomes enduring.
Cultivate it in the state—its virtue becomes bountiful.
Cultivate it in the world—its virtue becomes universal.

Therefore:
Observe the self through the self;
observe the family through the family;
observe the village through the village;
observe the state through the state;
observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

Establishing the center and standing firm—thus it cannot be uprooted.
Embracing the One without separation—thus it cannot slip away.
Children beget grandchildren, manifesting through division—thus sacrifices never cease.

Self, family, village, state, and world—these are the realms where virtue is cultivated.
*With* (由): through.
*Observe* (观): to demonstrate the method.
Through the self, demonstrate the Dharma-body;
extend this to demonstrate the Dharma-body in family, state, and world—
all are this true body.
When virtue is complete in the self, the demonstration is inexhaustible,
thus by this I universally know the world.

---

**Chapter Fifty-Five**
*(He Shang Gong’s commentary titles this "The Chapter on the Mysterious Token"; Peng’s edition titles it "The Chapter on Embracing Virtue")*

One who embraces profound virtue
is like an infant:
poisonous creatures do not sting,
fierce beasts do not seize,
grasping birds of prey do not strike.
Bones weak, sinews soft, yet the grip is firm.
Unknowing of the union of female and male, yet the organ stirs—
such is the perfection of essence.
All day crying, yet the throat does not grow hoarse—
such is the perfection of harmony.

To know harmony is called constancy;
to know constancy is called clarity.
To augment life is called auspicious.
The heart directing qi is called force.

When things reach their prime, they age—
this is called "not the Dao."
What is not the Dao soon perishes.

*Embrace* (含): to hold within.
Those who hold virtue profoundly are true persons.
The heart of the true person never loses the heart of an infant,
thus they are like an infant, utterly forgetful of externals.
Therefore, noxious creatures, beasts, or birds harm them.
Bones weak, sinews soft—this is the body of a child,
thus the grip is firm.
People know the joy of male-female union,
yet such knowledge leads to the stirring of the organ and the loss of life.
The infant, without knowledge, embodies the perfection of pure essence—
this is the absence of desire.
*Organ* (朘): the infant’s yin; also, contraction.
Vulgarly, *retraction* is called *朘缩*—contraction without arousal.
People, through anger, disrupt their harmony, and their voices grow hoarse.
The infant, however, may cry and wail yet never grow hoarse.
*Cry* (号) is calling; *wail* (嗌) is sobbing.
All day calling and sobbing without hoarseness—
such is the perfection of harmony.
One who knows harmony abides in constancy without peril.
I who know constancy attain true clarity.
What benefits human life is the infant’s auspicious harmony.
Yet if one possesses knowledge and awareness,
using the heart to direct qi,
they turn from softness to force.
Those who love force in the world—
have they ever observed this in things?
The explanation of the final three lines appears in Chapter Thirty.

chunks.original_text: （河上公注本作玄德章，彭本作玄同章） 知者不言，言者不知。 塞其兑，闭其门，挫其锐，解其纷，和其光，同其尘，是谓玄同。 不可得而亲，不可得而疏，不可得而利，不可得而害，不可得而贵，不要得而贱。 故为天下贵。 知者，是行有所得之人。 不言者，难言也。 盖其深造自得，心欲言而口不逮也。 若徒以言为尚，自谓某仙真书，真传已尽，不必师指，其道可行。 岂知真固真矣，其间细微节目，比喻深机，吾恐其未尽谈也。 又，况登真入道，不外还丹。 还丹理明，乃能得道。 今问汝，乾坤坎兑，是甚卦爻？ 龙虎汞铅，是甚法物？ 宾主雌雄，是甚分用？ 恍惚杳冥，从何体认？ 浮沉颠倒，怎样安排？ 而且玄牝未明，不能造化。 黄婆未请，安得成亲？ 兼之言语难通，恩威难布，首经难觅，火候难知。 且更有说者，古人云：金丹大事，须依有力者图之。 访寻有力之妙用，问君载在何书？ 矧其功夫行持，并有书不能贷者。 绝色欲，轻财利，去恩爱，慎德行，此皆要身上持行，而非书所能了者也。 夫惟真心好道，感动上苍，尘念消除，神明默佑，乃能知其道也。 按图索骥，岂足以竟其微哉？ 是故知者不言，言者不知也，以其有难言者也。 或曰：“知之者固属难言，以彼未知之光，却又从何闻之？ 岂不有能言者导其知乎？ 丹经云：得师口诀，乃能成道。 又似知者之必有言，言者之必有知也。 请再为说之。 ”曰：口诀者，亲切语也，细微语也。 重重抉破，乃为口诀。 并非单词只字，三言两句之为口诀也。 黄帝访广成，细谈三日。 吾师遇钟祖，坐论一旬。 天亶圣人，上根仙器，犹非几句可了，况其下乎？ 今人以口诀为捷传，皆非也。 口诀未尽，师去还来。 讲究之时，熟闻心记。 可以串通乎古书，发明乎层次。 此即口诀之妙也，人读丹经既多，一闻口诀，便可豁然开悟。 以经印诀，以诀印经，真实不虚，合乎大道。 此真师之所以当求，聪明之所以难恃也。 又况真师本根，原系阴德之土，修炼而成，岂不知重玄秘语，天所以与善人，而不以与非人者？ 若知之而轻言之，则紫阳何以三谴乎？ 其不言也，实不敢轻言耳。 即或大器相逢，传薪念切，亦必屡试屡磨。 弟勤师苦，而后盟香敷说钵传。 此日派衍将来，慎勿闻之而不行，又勿得之而自秘也。 言之如此，不其难乎？ 愚注《道德经》，虽比先贤解释分外详明，然其逐章注疏，依经遗言，而于丹道妙机，不能成段写出。 英雄志士，幸觅明师指破之，其得法更为易也。 因注此章首二句而细论之。 塞兑闭门，养神气也。 挫锐而不为锐挫，能守弱也。 解纷而不为纷扰，能泰定也。 和光而幽光，同尘而出尘。 孟子曰：圣人之于民亦类也。 此即玄同之旨也。 故不可得而亲，不可得而疏。 可得而亲，则可得而疏也。 不可利害，不可贵贱，亦如此也。 故为天下之至贵，无复有贵于圣德者。 第五十七章 （河上公注本作淳风章，彭本作以正章） 以正治国，以奇用兵，以无事取天下。 吾何以知其然乎？ 以此。

(This chapter is titled *The Chapter of Mysterious Virtue* in the Heshang Gong commentary and *The Chapter of Mysterious Sameness* in Peng’s version.)

Those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know.
Block the apertures, shut the gates,
blunt the sharpness, untangle the knots,
soften the light, merge with the dust—
this is called *mysterious sameness*.

It cannot be approached with intimacy,
nor distanced with estrangement;
it cannot be gained through profit,
nor harmed by injury;
it cannot be exalted as noble,
nor debased as lowly.
Thus it is most precious under heaven.

Those who *know* are those who have attained through practice. *Not speaking* is because speech is difficult. For their understanding runs deep, and though the heart wishes to speak, the mouth cannot keep pace. If one merely exalts speech, claiming some immortal’s scripture or true transmission has exhausted all that needs to be said—no teacher’s guidance required, the Dao can be practiced—how can they know that while the truth is indeed true, its subtle details, its layered metaphors, its profound mechanisms may yet elude them? Moreover, ascending to truth and entering the Dao ultimately depend on the *returned elixir*. Only when the principle of the returned elixir is clear can one attain the Dao.

Now, let me ask you:
*Qian* and *Kun*, *Kan* and *Dui*—what trigrams are these?
Dragon and tiger, mercury and lead—what alchemical substances are these?
Guest and host, female and male—how are they distinguished in function?
The indistinct and the obscure—how are they embodied?
The floating and the sinking, the inverted and the upright—how are they arranged?
Without clarity on the *mysterious female*, one cannot engage in transformation.
Without summoning the *Yellow Dame*, how can union be achieved?
Beyond this, words are hard to convey,
authority hard to establish,
the primary scripture hard to find,
the firing times hard to grasp.

Furthermore, as the ancients said: *The great matter of the golden elixir must be pursued with the help of one who has power.* Where in which book is the wondrous use of such a powerful one recorded? Moreover, the practice and discipline of the work include elements that cannot be conveyed by books alone: cutting off sensual desire,轻财利, relinquishing affection, guarding virtue—these are all matters of personal cultivation, not things that can be resolved through texts.

Only when a sincere heart seeks the Dao,
moving heaven above,
dissolving worldly thoughts,
and receiving the silent aid of the numinous,
can one come to know the Dao.
To seek a steed by following a picture—how can this suffice to grasp its subtleties?
Thus, *those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know*—because there are things that are difficult to speak of.

Some may ask: *"If knowing is indeed difficult to speak of, how can those who are yet unenlightened come to hear of it? Must there not be those who can speak to guide their knowing?"* The alchemical classics say: *Only with a teacher’s oral instructions can one attain the Dao.* This seems to imply that those who know must speak, and those who speak must know. Let me explain further.

*Oral instructions* are intimate words, subtle words—layer upon layer of breakthroughs, not mere isolated phrases or a few sentences. When the Yellow Emperor sought out Guangchengzi, they spoke in detail for three days. When my teacher met Ancestor Zhong, they sat in discussion for ten days. Even for those of heavenly sincerity and the highest spiritual capacity, a few words cannot suffice—how much less for those below?

Today, people mistake *oral instructions* for shortcuts; this is wrong. When oral instructions are incomplete, the teacher departs and returns. During discussion, one listens closely and commits to memory, so as to connect with ancient texts and illuminate the stages. This is the wonder of oral instructions. When one has read many alchemical classics, a single hearing of oral instructions can bring sudden awakening. The classics verify the instructions, and the instructions verify the classics—true and unfailing, in accord with the great Dao. This is why a true teacher must be sought, and why mere cleverness cannot be relied upon.

Moreover, the root of a true teacher lies in one who has cultivated virtue and refined it into attainment. How could they not know the profound and secret words that heaven bestows upon the good and withholds from the unworthy? If one knows yet speaks lightly of them, why did Master Ziyang receive three divine reprimands? Their silence is not unwillingness to speak, but a reluctance to speak lightly.

Even when great vessels meet and the transmission is urgent, the teacher must repeatedly test and refine the disciple. Only after the disciple’s diligence and the teacher’s toil do they swear an oath, light incense, and pass on the bowl of transmission. From this day forward, the lineage extends into the future—take care not to hear and fail to practice, nor to receive and hoard in secret. Given all this, is speaking not difficult?

In my commentary on the *Daodejing*, though more detailed than those of earlier scholars, each chapter’s annotations follow the text and leave its words intact, unable to fully articulate the wondrous mechanisms of the alchemical Dao in complete passages. Heroes and aspirants, if you can find a wise teacher to point them out, attaining the method will be all the easier.

*Blocking the apertures and shutting the gates* nurtures spirit and qi.
*Blunting sharpness* without being blunted by sharpness—this is the ability to guard weakness.
*Untangling knots* without being entangled by them—this is the ability to remain serene.
*Softening the light* to conceal its brilliance,
*merging with the dust* to transcend it—
Mencius said: *The sage’s relation to the people is also like this.*
This is the essence of *mysterious sameness*.

Thus, it cannot be approached with intimacy, nor distanced with estrangement. If it could be approached with intimacy, it could also be distanced with estrangement. The same applies to profit and harm, nobility and lowliness. Therefore, it is the most precious under heaven—nothing surpasses the sage’s virtue.

**Chapter Fifty-Seven**
(In the Heshang Gong commentary, titled *The Chapter of Pure Wind*; in Peng’s version, *The Chapter of Governing with Rectitude*)

Govern the state with rectitude,
deploy troops with奇,
win the world through non-interference.
How do I know this is so?
By this.

chunks.original_text: 天下多忌讳，而民弥贫。 民多利器，国家滋昏。 民多技巧，奇物滋起。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正，我无事而民自富，我无欲而民自朴。 正，非徒端拱也，实有能敬之教，使之感孚。 奇，非同诡诈也，实有静镇之教，使人难测。 故必以正治国，以奇用兵焉。 无事取天下，无为而成功也。 以此者，以治身之道，知治世之道也。 朝多忌讳，则贪鄙之臣进，故能使民贫。 民多利器，则机诈之徒起，故国家滋昏。 至于技巧悦君，必多奇淫之物。 法令侮民，必多盗贼之属。 此皆治理之变也。 故复引圣人所言，以观其治道之常，盖在于有欲、无欲之分耳。 第五十八章 （河上公注本作顺化章，彭本作其政章） 其政閟閟，其民醇醇。 其政察察，其民缺缺。 祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 孰知其极，其无正耶。 正复为奇，善复为妖。 民之迷，其日固久。 是以圣人方而不割，廉而不刿，直而不肆，光不而耀。 閟閟：敦朴貌。 醇醇：安静貌。 政敦其朴，民安于静矣。 察察：刻核也。 缺缺：疏忽也。 政好刻核，民多疏忽矣。 祸福倚伏之端，人正知其极而守其正。 敦知二字，言外有叹人不知之意。 不知其极，则亦无守正者耶。 夫正本直道，乃复变为奇邪，因无正也。 善本祥和，乃复变为妖孽，亦因无正也。 然则民入迷途，夫岂朝夕之故哉？ 割：裁截。 刿：伤残也。 肆：径行。 耀：炫异也。 四者皆民之迷也。 惟圣人大方无隅，而不假裁截。 清廉自守，而不致伤残。 履直韬光，则得道之正轨也。 第五十九章 （河上公注本作守道章，彭本作根蒂章）
chunks.translated_text:
The world abounds with taboos, and the people grow ever poorer. The people possess many sharp tools, and the state sinks deeper into chaos. The people cultivate many clever skills, and strange artifacts proliferate. Laws and decrees multiply, and thieves and bandits abound. Thus the sage declares: *I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves; I cherish stillness, and the people rectify themselves; I engage in no affairs, and the people enrich themselves; I harbor no desires, and the people return to simplicity.*

Rectitude is not mere idle governance—it truly embodies the teaching of reverence, moving people to respond with sincerity. The extraordinary is not mere deceit—it truly embodies the teaching of quiet mastery, making one’s intentions inscrutable. Thus one must govern the state with rectitude and deploy troops with the extraordinary. To win the world through non-interference is to achieve success through non-action. By this, I mean: the Way of cultivating the self reveals the Way of governing the world.

When the court teems with taboos, corrupt and base ministers advance, impoverishing the people. When the people possess many sharp tools, scheming and deceitful men arise, plunging the state into deeper chaos. When clever skills please the ruler, strange and extravagant objects multiply. When laws and decrees disdain the people, thieves and bandits flourish. These are all perversions of good governance.

Thus the sage’s words are recalled to observe the constancy of the Way of governance—it lies solely in the distinction between having desires and having none.

**Chapter Fifty-Eight**
*(In the Heshang Gong commentary, titled *The Chapter of Harmonious Transformation*; in Peng’s version, *The Chapter of Governance*)*

When governance is muted and unobtrusive, the people are simple and sincere.
When governance is sharp and exacting, the people are restless and lacking.
Misfortune—fortune leans upon it;
Fortune—misfortune lurks within it.
Who knows their ultimate end? Is there no constancy?
Rectitude reverts to the extraordinary,
Goodness reverts to the ominous.
The people’s delusion has endured for long indeed.

Therefore the sage is square but does not cut,
sharp but does not wound,
straight but does not stretch,
luminous but does not dazzle.

*Muted and unobtrusive (閟閟)*: a manner of honest simplicity.
*Simple and sincere (醇醇)*: a state of tranquil composure.
When governance fosters simplicity, the people rest in stillness.
*Sharp and exacting (察察)*: harsh and demanding.
*Restless and lacking (缺缺)*: negligent and careless.
When governance is harsh and demanding, the people grow negligent.

The beginnings of fortune and misfortune’s mutual dependence—people should know their ultimate end and uphold constancy. The phrase *"who knows"* implies a lament that people do not understand. If one does not know the ultimate end, how can there be any who uphold constancy?

Rectitude, the straight path, reverts to the extraordinary and perverse—all because there is no constancy. Goodness, originally auspicious, reverts to the ominous and baleful—also because there is no constancy. If this is so, how could the people’s descent into delusion be the fault of a single morning or evening?

*Cut*: to sever.
*Wound*: to injure.
*Stretch*: to act without restraint.
*Dazzle*: to display ostentation.
These four are the delusions of the people.

Only the sage is vast and uncornered, requiring no severing;
pure and self-contained, avoiding injury;
straight yet restrained, never overreaching;
radiant yet not dazzling—thus walking the true path of the Dao.

*(In the Heshang Gong commentary, titled *The Chapter of Guarding the Dao*; in Peng’s version, *The Chapter of Roots and Foundations*)*

chunks.original_text: 治人事天，莫如啬，是谓早服。 早服谓之重积德，重积德则无不克，无不克则莫知其极，莫知其极，可以有国。 有国之母。 可以长久。 是谓深根固蒂，长生久视之道。 啬：俭也。 早服：以富国安民言。 积德； 以民安国富言。 克，胜也。 犹言治事崇俭，则能富国安民，而使民安国富，战无不胜也。 战无不胜，则莫知其所穷极。 驯至于泽厚仁深，必可以得国矣。 国，指邦本言。 邦本既立，则投真砂于玉池，而先造其铅母。 铅母擒汞子，则可以享国长久矣。 是谓深根固蒂之修，长生久视之道。 根蒂者，归根以伏其气，养蒂以全其神也。 第六十章 （河上公注本作居位章，彭本作烹鲜章）
chunks.translated_text:
Governing people and serving Heaven—nothing compares to frugality; this is called "early compliance." "Early compliance" means accumulating virtue in abundance. Accumulating virtue in abundance leads to invincibility; being invincible means none can fathom its limits. When none can fathom its limits, one may possess the state. Possessing the state’s foundational power, one may endure long. This is the Dao of deep roots and firm stems, the Way of long life and enduring vision.

*Frugality*: thrift.
*Early compliance*: referring to enriching the state and pacifying the people.
*Accumulating virtue*: referring to the people’s peace and the state’s prosperity.
*Invincibility*: triumph.
To say it plainly: governing with reverence for thrift enables the enrichment of the state and pacification of the people, ensuring their peace and the state’s prosperity, and rendering all battles victorious. Being ever-victorious, none can discern its bounds. Gradually, with profound benevolence and deep kindness, one may surely attain the state. The *state* here refers to the nation’s foundation. Once the foundation is established, one casts true cinnabar into the jade pool, first refining the lead-mother. When the lead-mother captures the mercury-child, the state may be enjoyed long. This is the cultivation of deep roots and firm stems, the Way of long life and enduring vision.

*Roots and stems*: returning to the root to subdue one’s qi, nurturing the stem to preserve one’s spirit.

chunks.original_text: 治大国，若烹小鲜。 以道莅天下，其鬼不神。 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人。 非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 夫两不相伤，故德交归焉。 烹与割不同，割尚分析，烹尚调和。 小鲜：小物也。 视大国如小物，只在乎调和民情而已。 鬼：魔也。 神：灵也。 不伤：不扰也。 犹言以道立治，魔虽灵而不扰。 非不扰人也，圣人以静治而不扰人，魔又何敢扰人哉？ 故魔与人两忘，而为圣德治伏也。 交归：咸服也。 第六十一章 （河上公注本作谦德章，彭本作下流章） 大国者下流，天下之交，天下之牝。 牝常以静胜牡，以静为下。 故大国以下小国，则取小国。 小国以下大国，则取大国。 故或下以取，或下而取。 大国大过，欲兼畜人。 小国小过，欲入事人。 夫两者各得其所欲，故大者宜为下。 此章示天下诸侯当修下以怀小邦也。 下流为众水所归，比大国之统下国，故曰大国者下流，非言居下流也。 管合附庸，故称为天下之交。 当用柔德，故譬以天下之牝。 牝：柔道也。 牡，刚道也。 小国虽刚，大国以柔静胜之，故静为谦下之德也。 大国谦下于小国，则小国乐为社稷之臣，每岁可收其供给。 小国谦下于大国，则大国尝有奖赏之意，每年可邀其赍予。 故或谦下以取之，或居下而取之。 大小本相资也。 大国有大过象，老夫得女，过以相与，故有欲兼畜人之德，言欲生全小国也。 小国有小过亨，与时偕行，过以利贞，故有欲入事人之道，言欲依附大国也。 大小各得其欲，皆因大之下小也。 否则小国之君，虽欲臣事大国，而大国强凌，小亦不悦服于大也。 太上大旨，本为大国诸侯讲柔远相资之义，而于修身微旨，亦自双关得妙。 今试言之： 大国者，昆仑也。 下流者，元海也。 昆仑之津，下归于元海，言元海而昆仑相接，故曰大国者下流，非言昆仑居下流也。 下流之地，当天下之交。 交者，附也。 众服依附在于此，即所谓黄庭也。 下流之德，为天下之牝。 牝，柔也。 专气致柔在于此，故称为牝户也。 牝户一穴，元精在内，静摄肾气于其中，故其先以肾为牝门，以心为牡。 而今又以我为牝，以彼为牡。 盖颠倒其刚柔，非颠倒其牝牡也。 心火，其性刚躁，水之静能制火之动，此即铅之来，能制汞之飞也。 以静为下者，用默、用柔，修谦下以定心性也。 故昆仑美液，流入元海。 液又化气，而入丹田。 大国下小国，即由昆仑到丹田也。 取小国者，采取丹田金水，逆转天谷也。 小国下大国，又从丹田到昆仑也。 取大国者，并合昆仑金液，共落黄庭也。 故或昆仑之液，流下丹田以生气，则取丹田之气者，是为下以取也。 抑或丹田之气，逆上昆仑以生液，则吞昆仑之液者，是为下而取也。 大国大过者，实取法于易道矣。 泽风之卦，利于攸往，故象词以泽灭木为喻。 盖言泽水高涨，而其木皆淹，是为大过之象也。 上昆仑之甘露下降，原以攸往为亨，与大过正相合焉，神化气而气化精，将以充满丹田也。 故有欲兼畜人之德。 小国小过者，亦取法于易道矣。 雷山之卦，利于守贞，故象词以鸟遗音为喻，犹言飞鸟宜下，则其音可闻，是为小过之象也。 下丹田之真液中涵，原以守贞为吉，与小过正相符焉。 精生气而气生神，将以飞依黄庭也，故有欲入事人之道。
chunks.translated_text:
Governing a great state is like cooking a small fish.

With the Dao presiding over the world, its ghosts lose their numinosity.
Not that its ghosts lose their numinosity—
their numinosity does no harm to people.
Not that their numinosity does no harm to people—
the sage also does no harm to people.
When the two do not harm one another,
their virtues converge and return.

Cooking differs from cutting: cutting values separation, while cooking values harmony.
*Small fish*: small things.
Viewing a great state as a small thing lies solely in harmonizing the people’s sentiments.

*Ghosts*: demons.
*Numinosity*: spirits.
*Does no harm*: does not disturb.
This means that with the Dao as the foundation of governance, though demons possess spirit, they do not disturb.
It is not that they do not disturb people—
the sage governs with stillness and does not disturb people,
so how dare demons disturb them?
Thus, demons and people forget one another,
and the sage’s virtue subdues all.

*Converge and return*: all submit.

**Chapter Sixty-One**
*(In the Heshang Gong commentary, titled *The Chapter of Humble Virtue*; in Peng’s version, *The Chapter of Lower Currents*)*

A great state is the lower current,
the confluence of the world,
the female of the world.
The female always overcomes the male with stillness,
using stillness as her lower position.

Thus, when a great state humbles itself before a small state,
it wins over the small state.
When a small state humbles itself before a great state,
it wins over the great state.
Therefore, some win by humbling themselves,
while others win by being humble.

A great state, being too great, desires to shelter others.
A small state, being too small, desires to serve others.
When both attain what they desire,
the greater should remain humble.

This chapter instructs the lords of the world to cultivate humility in order to embrace smaller states.
*Lower current*: where all waters converge, likened to a great state uniting lesser ones.
Thus, a great state is the lower current—not that it dwells in a lowly position.
It unites tributary states, hence called the confluence of the world.
It should employ gentle virtue, thus compared to the female of the world.

*Female*: the Way of softness.
*Male*: the Way of hardness.
Though small states may be hard, a great state overcomes them with soft stillness,
so stillness is the virtue of humility.

When a great state humbles itself before a small state,
the small state delights in serving as its vassal,
and each year may offer tribute.
When a small state humbles itself before a great state,
the great state often rewards it,
and each year may bestow gifts.
Thus, some win by humbling themselves,
while others win by being humble.
Great and small naturally rely on one another.

A great state, in its excess, resembles the *Great Exceeding* hexagram:
an old man obtaining a young woman—
excessive yet harmonious—
thus possessing the virtue of sheltering others,
meaning it seeks to preserve small states.
A small state, in its modest success, resembles the *Small Exceeding* hexagram:
moving with the times—
excessive yet properly aligned—
thus possessing the Way of serving others,
meaning it seeks to depend on great states.
When great and small each attain their desires,
it is because the greater humbles itself before the lesser.
Otherwise, though the ruler of a small state may wish to serve a great state,
if the great state oppresses it,
the small state will not willingly submit.

The grand purport of this teaching is to instruct the lords of great states in the principle of gentle reciprocity with distant lands,
yet its subtle implications for self-cultivation are equally profound.

Let us now expound it:

The *great state* is Kunlun.
The *lower current* is the primordial sea.
The fluids of Kunlun descend into the primordial sea,
meaning the primordial sea connects with Kunlun—
thus, a great state is the lower current,
not that Kunlun dwells in a lowly position.

The *lower current* is the confluence of the world.
*Confluence*: attachment.
All submission and dependence reside here—
this is the Yellow Court.

The virtue of the lower current is the female of the world.
*Female*: softness.
Concentrating qi to achieve softness lies here,
hence it is called the female gate.

Within the female gate’s cavity resides primordial essence.
By quietly gathering kidney qi within it,
the kidneys are first regarded as the female gate,
and the heart as the male.
Yet now, the self is considered female,
and the other male—
this reverses hardness and softness,
not female and male.

The heart’s fire is by nature hard and restless;
water’s stillness can restrain fire’s movement—
this is the coming of lead,
which can restrain mercury’s flight.

*Using stillness as her lower position*:
employing silence and softness,
cultivating humility to stabilize the heart-mind.

Thus, Kunlun’s sweet fluids flow into the primordial sea.
The fluids transform into qi,
entering the cinnabar field.
A great state humbling itself before a small state
is like descending from Kunlun to the cinnabar field.
*Winning over the small state*:
gathering the cinnabar field’s metal-water,
reversing its flow to the celestial valley.
A small state humbling itself before a great state
is like ascending from the cinnabar field to Kunlun.
*Winning over the great state*:
merging Kunlun’s golden fluids,
both descending into the Yellow Court.

Thus, when Kunlun’s fluids flow down to the cinnabar field to generate qi,
gathering the cinnabar field’s qi is *winning by humbling oneself*.
Or when the cinnabar field’s qi ascends to Kunlun to generate fluids,
swallowing Kunlun’s fluids is *winning by being humble*.

The *great state’s excess* is modeled on the Dao of the *Yi*.
The *Marsh Wind* hexagram is favorable for advancement,
its image likening marsh water submerging wood—
when marsh waters rise high,
all trees are submerged,
this is the image of *Great Exceeding*.
When Kunlun’s sweet dew descends,
it originally advances with success,
aligning perfectly with *Great Exceeding*—
spirit transforms into qi,
and qi transforms into essence,
which fills the cinnabar field.
Thus, it possesses the virtue of sheltering others.

The *small state’s modest success* is also modeled on the Dao of the *Yi*.
The *Thunder Mountain* hexagram is favorable for maintaining integrity,
its image likening a bird’s lingering call—
just as a flying bird should descend,
so its call may be heard,
this is the image of *Small Exceeding*.
When the lower cinnabar field’s true fluids are contained within,
originally maintaining integrity is auspicious,
aligning perfectly with *Small Exceeding*—
essence generates qi,
and qi generates spirit,
which ascends to depend on the Yellow Court.
Thus, it possesses the Way of serving others.

chunks.original_text: 一上一下，相资相守，颠倒乾坤，逆运黄河。 修身妙诀，莫过于此。 补注：故或数句，一作故黄庭居下，以收昆仑之液者，则为下以取。 又，或黄庭照下，以摄丹田之气者，则为下而取。 此义亦可参观。 吾山评：黄庭为养心之府，牝户为养肾之源。 今以养心者，称为牝户，盖以存神保精，道贵静也。 凝神聚气，道贵柔也。 虚神受气，道贵谦也。 守神候气，道贵弱也。 以神交气，道贵下也。 调和神气，道贵和也。 牝道有静、柔、谦、弱、下和之六德，故借牝户之名，权易黄庭之名，非移户之地于黄庭间也。 修丹家颠倒法物卦爻，每多互相借名耳。 涵虚直言之，回道人更加发明，一句一真诀，扫尽千百譬喻也。 得者宝之，非人勿示。 第六十二章 （河上公注本作为道章，彭本作道奥道） 道者万物之奥。 善人之宝，不善人之所保。 美言可以市，尊行可以加人。 人之不善，何弃之有？ 故立天子置三公，虽有拱璧以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 古之所以贵此道者何？ 不曰：求以得，有罪以免邪？ 故为天下贵。 万物之奥，犹言造化之源也。 善人则宝重之，以修丹而作圣。 不善人亦保全之，可补气而延年。 此道之至公也。 善言此道，可使从者如市。 尊行此道，可以加人一等。 此道之不负人也。 世之弃道之驰者，人自不善耳，道何尝弃人者？ 故以天子三公之贵人，拱璧驷马之贵物，而与道相较，终不如坐进此道之为贵也。 坐：守也。 《左传》：楚人坐其北门是也。 又，跪也。 《曲礼》：坐则迁之是也。 夫古之所以贵此道者，以其求则得之，得则免罪也。 故天下之贵，莫贵于此。 不曰者，古不云乎之词也。 第六十三章 （河上公注本作恩始章，彭本作为大章） 为无为，事无事，味无味。 大小多少，报怨以德。 图难于其易，为大于其细。 天下难事，必作于易。 天下大事，必作于细。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 夫轻诺必寡信，多易必多难。 是以圣人犹难之，故终无难。 为无为之为，事无为之事，味无味之味，皆指恬静澹泊也。 大小多少，称物平施也。 报怨以德者，以直报，即以德报也，非有所加厚也。 图难于易者，人之轻易，我独难之，不是先难后易也。 为大于细者，不矜细行，终累大德。 此与书言同也，故又曰天下难事，必作于易。 天下大事，必作于细。 可晓然也。 作于易，始于戒轻易也。 作于细，始于矜细行也。 圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 益明上文之必作于细也。 其必作于易者，更立论以明之。 譬如轻诺之人，必为寡信之人。 可知言多轻易之人，必终为行多难成之人也。 是以不难者，圣人犹难之，故终无难也。 第六十四章 其安易持，其未兆易谋。 其脆易破，其微易散。 为之于未有，治之于未乱。 合抱之木，生于毫末。 九层之台，起于累土。 千里之行，始于足下。 为者败之，执者失之。 圣人无为，故无败。 无执，故无失。 民之从事，常于几成而败之。 慎终如始，则无败事。 是以圣人欲不欲，不贵难得之货。 学不学，复众人之所过，以辅万物之自然而不敢为。 凡修大道者，从安定时持之则易持，否则欲起难持也。 从未兆时谋之则易谋，否则物走难谋也。 脆弱者易破，微芒者易散，盖言嫩之难得，小之难捉也。
chunks.translated_text:
One ascends and one descends, mutually supporting and preserving,
inverting Heaven and Earth,
reversing the flow of the Yellow River.
The wondrous secret of cultivating the body lies in nothing beyond this.

**Supplementary Annotation:**
Thus, some say: "When the Yellow Court resides below to gather the fluids of Kunlun, it is *taking by descending*."
Others say: "When the Yellow Court illuminates below to absorb the qi of the cinnabar field, it is *taking by descending*."
This meaning may also be considered.

**Wu Shan’s Commentary:**
The Yellow Court is the palace for nurturing the heart,
while the *mysterious gate* is the source for nurturing the kidneys.
Now, what nurtures the heart is called the *mysterious gate*—
for in preserving spirit and guarding essence, the Dao values stillness.
In congealing spirit and gathering qi, the Dao values softness.
In the empty spirit receiving qi, the Dao values humility.
In guarding spirit and awaiting qi, the Dao values weakness.
In spirit uniting with qi, the Dao values lowliness.
In harmonizing spirit and qi, the Dao values harmony.
The *mysterious gate* possesses the six virtues of stillness, softness, humility, weakness, lowliness, and harmony.
Thus, it borrows the name of the *mysterious gate* to provisionally replace the name of the Yellow Court—
this is not to move the gate’s location into the Yellow Court.
Those who practice the elixir often invert the trigrams and lines of the hexagrams, frequently borrowing names from one another.
When Hanxu speaks plainly, and Master Huidao further elucidates,
each phrase is a true secret,
sweeping away a thousand analogies.
Those who attain it should treasure it; do not show it to the unworthy.

---

**Chapter Sixty-Two**
*(He Shanggong’s edition titles this "The Dao Chapter"; Peng’s edition titles it "The Mystery of the Dao")*

The Dao is the mystery of the ten thousand things.
It is the treasure of the good,
and the refuge of the unworthy.
Fair words can be traded in the marketplace,
and noble conduct can elevate a person.
If people are unworthy, how can they be abandoned?
Thus, when the Son of Heaven is established and the Three Dukes are appointed,
though one may offer a jade disk preceded by a team of four horses,
it is not as valuable as sitting and advancing in this Dao.

Why was this Dao prized in ancient times?
Was it not said: "Seek and you shall obtain; with it, even the guilty may be absolved"?
Thus, it is the most precious under heaven.

"The mystery of the ten thousand things" means the source of creation.
The good treasure it to refine the elixir and become a sage.
Even the unworthy preserve it to replenish qi and prolong life.
This is the utmost impartiality of the Dao.

Fine words about this Dao can make followers gather like a marketplace.
Exalted practice of this Dao can elevate a person.
The Dao does not fail anyone.
Those who abandon the Dao and run astray are unworthy themselves—
the Dao has never abandoned anyone.
Thus, when comparing the noble ones like the Son of Heaven and the Three Dukes,
or the precious objects like jade disks and teams of four horses,
with the Dao,
none is as valuable as sitting and advancing in this Dao.

*Sitting* means *guarding*. As in the *Zuozhuan*: "The people of Chu *guarded* their northern gate."
It also means *kneeling*. As in the *Classic of Rites*: "When *kneeling*, one shifts position."

Why was this Dao prized in ancient times?
Because by seeking it, one obtains it,
and by obtaining it, one is absolved of guilt.
Thus, nothing under heaven is as precious as this.
*"Was it not said"* is an archaic phrase meaning *"Did the ancients not say?"*

---

**Chapter Sixty-Three**
*(He Shanggong’s edition titles this "Beginning with Grace"; Peng’s edition titles it "The Great Chapter")*

Act without acting,
attend to affairs without affairs,
taste without tasting.
Regard the great as small, the many as few,
and repay resentment with virtue.
Address difficulties while they are easy,
achieve greatness while it is small.
The difficult affairs of the world must arise from the easy.
The great affairs of the world must arise from the small.
Thus, the sage never acts as great,
and therefore accomplishes greatness.

One who makes promises lightly will surely lack trust;
one who treats things lightly will surely encounter many difficulties.
Thus, the sage treats even the difficult as difficult,
and therefore ultimately encounters no difficulty.

*Acting without acting*, *attending to affairs without affairs*, *tasting without tasting*—
all refer to tranquility and simplicity.
*Regarding the great as small, the many as few*—
this is impartiality in dealing with things.
*Repaying resentment with virtue*—
responding with uprightness is itself repaying with virtue,
not adding extra generosity.

*Addressing difficulties while they are easy*—
when others treat things lightly, I alone treat them as difficult;
this is not putting the difficult before the easy.
*Achieving greatness while it is small*—
disdaining small conduct will ultimately harm great virtue.
This aligns with the *Book of Documents*.
Thus, it is also said: "The difficult affairs of the world must arise from the easy.
The great affairs of the world must arise from the small."
This is clearly understood.

*Arising from the easy* begins with caution against treating things lightly.
*Arising from the small* begins with valuing small conduct.
The sage never acts as great,
and therefore accomplishes greatness—
further clarifying that the above must *arise from the small*.

To emphasize that it must *arise from the easy*,
another argument is presented:
For example, one who makes promises lightly will surely become untrustworthy.
Thus, one who speaks lightly will surely end as one whose actions are difficult to accomplish.
Therefore, the sage treats even the undifficult as difficult,
and thus ultimately encounters no difficulty.

---

**Chapter Sixty-Four**

What is secure is easy to maintain;
what has no sign is easy to plan for.
What is fragile is easy to break;
what is minute is easy to scatter.
Act before things arise,
govern before disorder begins.
A tree of arm-spanning girth grows from a tiny sprout.
A nine-tiered terrace rises from a basket of earth.
A journey of a thousand *li* begins with a single step.
One who acts will fail;
one who grasps will lose.
The sage acts not, and thus does not fail.
He does not grasp, and thus does not lose.

In their undertakings, people often fail when near completion.
If one is as cautious at the end as at the beginning,
there will be no failure.

Thus, the sage desires what others do not desire,
and does not value rare goods.
He learns what others do not learn,
restoring what the multitude has passed over,
to assist the self-so of the ten thousand things without daring to act.

For those cultivating the great Dao:
What is secure is easy to maintain—otherwise, when trouble arises, it is difficult to hold.
What has no sign is easy to plan for—otherwise, when things have gone astray, it is difficult to plan.
The fragile is easy to break; the minute is easy to scatter—
this speaks of the difficulty of preserving the tender and the challenge of seizing the small.

chunks.translated_text:
At the stage of non-being, action ensures what is secure may be maintained, and what has no sign may be planned for. Governing before disorder arises ensures the fragile does not break and the minute does not scatter. How can one not be cautious in their method?

Moreover, progress in skill must be gradual, lest there be cause for retreat. It is like a living tree, growing from small to great; like building a terrace, rising from low to high; like traveling a road, advancing from near to far. These are clear proofs.

Those who act desire success but bring about failure. Those who grasp desire gain but incur loss. The sage, however, practices non-action. Yet even in non-action and non-grasping, one must remain unwavering from beginning to end to achieve completion.

I have often observed foolish people undertaking tasks, many failing when near success. How can one not be as cautious at the end as at the beginning?

Only the sage desires what others do not desire—desiring, he cherishes the Dao; not desiring, he scorns goods and values virtue. And he learns what others do not learn—learning, he possesses method; not learning, he remains serene in non-action. This is how he reverses the excesses of the multitude, assisting the self-so principle of the ten thousand things without daring to act.

As stated in the fifty-seventh chapter: *"I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves; I cherish stillness, and the people rectify themselves; I do nothing, and the people enrich themselves; I have no desires, and the people simplify themselves."* This is precisely the same principle.

chunks.translated_text:
The version of Heshang Gong’s commentary titles this the "Chapter on Pristine Virtue," while Peng’s version calls it the "Chapter on the People’s Simplicity."

Those adept in the Dao in ancient times did not seek to enlighten the people but instead to render them simple. The people are difficult to govern because of their excessive cleverness. Governing the state through cleverness is the state’s ruin; governing the state without cleverness is the state’s blessing. To understand these two paths is to grasp the model. One who comprehends this model is said to possess mysterious virtue. Mysterious virtue runs deep and far, reversing the course of things, and thus attaining great harmony.

The Dao does not value knowledge or discernment, for these diminish its undifferentiated wholeness; it values instead the state of not-knowing and not-discerning, thereby preserving its namelessness. Thus, those adept in the Dao do not seek to enlighten the people but to render them simple.

“The people are difficult to govern because of their excessive cleverness” echoes the earlier saying: “When cunning and wisdom arise, great falsity follows.” “Governing the state through cleverness is the state’s ruin” corresponds to: “The more meticulous the governance, the more deficient the people.” “Governing the state without cleverness is the state’s blessing” aligns with: “Abandon sagacity, discard wisdom, and the people will benefit a hundredfold.”

These two paths—cleverness and non-cleverness—truly determine the state’s fortune or misfortune and serve as the model for governance. One who understands this may be called possessed of mysterious virtue. Mysterious virtue sees profoundly, its radiance reaches far, appearing simple yet not simple, reversing the dullness of things. *Great harmony* means great transformation. Only through such mysterious virtue can one attain this great transformation.

chunks.original_text: 江海所以能为百谷王者，以其善下之，故能为百谷王。 是以圣人欲上人，必以言下之。 欲先人，必以身后之。 是以圣人处上而人不重，处前而人不害。 是以天下乐推而不厌，以其不争，故天下莫能与之争。 江海善下，群流归之，故称为百谷王，以观圣人。 欲上民而言下者，前所谓“高以下为基”也。 欲先人而身后者，前所谓“后其身而身先”也。 是以圣德冲和，在上无震慑之威，而民不饰矜重也。 当前无凌厉之气，而民不防患害也。 故天下推戴圣人，乐而不厌也.莫能与争者，圣人如江海之善下，百谷皆莫能分其势也。 第六十七章 （河上公注本作三宝章，彭本同）
chunks.translated_text:
The reason rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys is that they excel in staying low—thus they become kings of the hundred valleys. Therefore, when the sage wishes to rise above the people, they must speak as though beneath them. When they wish to lead the people, they must place themselves behind. Thus, though the sage stands above, the people do not feel burdened; though they stand ahead, the people do not feel harmed. Therefore, the world delights in exalting them without weariness. Because they do not contend, none in the world can contend with them.

Rivers and seas excel in staying low, so all streams flow toward them—hence they are called kings of the hundred valleys. This illustrates the sage. To rise above the people while speaking humbly is what was previously called “the high takes the low as its foundation.” To lead the people while placing oneself behind is what was previously called “putting oneself last, yet finding oneself first.” Thus, the sage’s virtue is empty and harmonious: standing above, they possess no awe-inspiring majesty, yet the people do not feign reverence; standing ahead, they carry no overbearing force, yet the people feel no need to guard against harm. Therefore, the world exalts the sage with joy and never tires of it. None can contend with them because the sage, like rivers and seas that excel in staying low, leaves the hundred valleys with no way to divide their power.

chunks.original_text: 天下皆谓我大，似不肖。 夫惟大，故似不肖。 若肖，久矣其细也夫！ 我有三宝，持而宝之。 一曰慈，二曰俭，三曰不敢为天下先。 慈故能勇，俭故能广，不敢为天下先，故能成器长。 今舍慈且勇，舍俭而广，舍其后且先，死矣。 夫慈以战则胜，以守则固。 天将救之，以慈卫之。 道本无方无体，以大称之。 是必有方体可拟，反不肖其大也。 惟大莫名其大，故不肖人之所谓大。 若肖人之所谓大，则大者而亦小也。 故曰“久矣其细”也。 太上以三宝为言，亦大之散见者耳。 一曰慈，慈必果于仁，故能勇。 二曰俭，俭必善于积，故能广。 三曰不敢为天下先，不敢先则大器晚成，故能成器长也。 然而舍慈为勇，必有忍心。 舍俭为广，必有贪心，舍后为先，必有争心。 皆取死之道也。 但以一、二、三分陈三宝，则一之为贵，故举慈以毕言之。 慈以战则胜，见义必为也。 以守则固，存仁必坚也。 救之者，以指人言。 天将救人，亦必以慈卫人也。 慈之为道大矣哉！ 第六十八章 （河上公注本作配天章，彭本同）
chunks.translated_text:
The world all calls me great, yet I seem unworthy. Precisely because I am great, I seem unworthy. Were I worthy, I would long since have been small!

I possess three treasures, which I hold and cherish:
The first is compassion,
The second is frugality,
The third is not daring to be first in the world.
Through compassion, one can be courageous;
Through frugality, one can be expansive;
Through not daring to be first in the world, one can become the vessel of leadership.

Now, to abandon compassion yet seek courage,
To abandon frugality yet seek expansion,
To abandon the last yet strive to be first—
This is the path to death.

With compassion, one triumphs in battle and stands firm in defense.
Heaven will save them, shielding them with compassion.

The Dao is fundamentally without form or body, yet it is called great. If it had a form or body to imitate, it would no longer resemble its greatness. Only the great cannot be named as great, and so it does not resemble what people call great. If it resembled what people call great, then even the great would be small. Hence it is said, “Were it worthy, it would long since have been small!”

The highest speaks of the three treasures, which are but scattered manifestations of greatness:
The first is compassion—compassion must be resolute in benevolence, thus it can be courageous.
The second is frugality—frugality must excel in accumulation, thus it can be expansive.
The third is not daring to be first in the world—not daring to be first means great vessels mature late, thus one can become the vessel of leadership.

Yet to abandon compassion for courage is to harbor a heart of cruelty.
To abandon frugality for expansion is to harbor a heart of greed.
To abandon the last for the first is to harbor a heart of contention.
All these are paths to death.

Though the three treasures are presented in order, the first is most noble, so compassion is emphasized to complete the discourse.
With compassion, one triumphs in battle—seeing righteousness, one must act.
With it, one stands firm in defense—preserving benevolence, one must be steadfast.
“Saving them” refers to humanity: Heaven will save people, and it too must shield them with compassion.

How great is the Dao of compassion!

(Heshang Gong’s commentary titles this the "Chapter on Matching Heaven," and Peng’s version concurs.)

chunks.original_text: 善为士者，不武。 善战者，不怒。 善胜敌者，不争。 善用人者，为之下。 是谓不争之德，是谓用人之力，是谓配天古之极。 恃力曰武，恃气曰怒，接杀曰争，皆非善为士，善为战，善胜敌者也。 古之用人者，敌中有虎将，常为谦下以招之，使彼释甲而来投，是谓不争之德，即所谓用人之力也。 且其德足以配天，天不竞功而成，旷古之极则也。 此章秘义，为修丹者言之欲伏白虎，先降真龙。 盖白虎为难制之物，龙不谦下，虎必奔逸。 炼己无净，乃能用虎之力也。 第六十九章 （河上公注本作玄用章，彭本作轻敌章）
chunks.translated_text:
A masterful warrior is not martial.
A masterful fighter is not enraged.
A masterful conqueror does not contend.
A masterful leader humbles himself before others.
This is called the virtue of non-contention,
This is called the power of employing others,
This is called matching the ancient ultimate of Heaven.

Reliance on force is called martiality,
Reliance on qi is called rage,
Engagement in slaughter is called contention—
None of these are the way of the masterful warrior, the masterful fighter, or the masterful conqueror.

Of old, those who masterfully employed others,
Even when facing a tiger-like general among their foes,
Would always humble themselves to summon him,
Causing him to lay down his armor and come in surrender.
This is called the virtue of non-contention,
That is, the power of employing others’ strength.
Moreover, such virtue suffices to match Heaven,
For Heaven does not vie for merit yet accomplishes all,
The ancient ultimate indeed.

The esoteric meaning of this chapter,
For those who cultivate the elixir,
Speaks of taming the White Tiger by first subduing the True Dragon.
For the White Tiger is a creature difficult to restrain,
And if the Dragon does not humble itself, the Tiger will surely flee.
Only when the self is refined without impurity
Can one wield the Tiger’s power.
